revision.comment: Adjusted amount of garlic. Other minor text adjustments
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Rice recipes|7|20 minutes|2|Image=[[Image:Chinese fried rice by stu spivack in Cleveland, OH.jpg|300px]]|100 kcal.}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of China|Cuisine of China]] | [[Cookbook:Rice|Rice]]
==Ingredients==
* 3 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Oil|corn oil]] * 2 tbsp. minced or finely chopped [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * 1/2 cup (100 g) [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]], diced * 1/2 cup (100 g) [[Cookbook:Prawn|prawn]] (shrimp), diced * 1/4 cup (50 g) Char siu (barbecued pork), diced * 1/8 cup (25 g) [[Cookbook:Scallion|scallion]], diced * 1/4 cup (50 g) [[Cookbook:Peas|peas]] * 1/2 cup (100 g) mixed [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]] * 3 cups (600 g) cooked [[Cookbook:rice|jasmine rice]] * 1 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * 2 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Jalapeno|jalapeno]], diced (optional)
==Procedure==
# Heat the oil on non-stick pan, fry the garlic until golden brown. Put the bacon, prawn and char siu, cook slightly at 5 minutes. # Add the scallion, peas and egg, cook until all cooked, and then add the rice, finally add the salt, pepper and jalapeno. # Serves 7.
{{wikipedia|Yeung Chow fried rice}}
[[Category:Rice recipes]] [[Category:Fried rice recipes]]

revision.comment: Koavf moved page [[Cookbook:Vegetarian fried rice]] to [[Cookbook:Vegetarian Fried Rice]]
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Rice recipes|5|1 hour|3||160 kcal.}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Rice|Rice]] | [[Cookbook:Fried rice|Fried rice]]
==Ingredients==
* 2 pack [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrot]], cut 5 * 1 * 1 cm * 1 pack [[Cookbook:Bean Sprout|bean sprouts]], soak in hot water * 1 pack [[Cookbook:Broccoli|broccoli]], soak in hot water * 1 pack [[Cookbook:Mushroom|mushroom]], soak in hot water, cut into 3 pieces * Half pack [[Cookbook:Cabbage|cabbage]], cut 2 cm * 4 [[Cookbook:Scallion|scallions]], cut 1,5 cm * 3 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Oil|corn oil]] * 3 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * 1/4 big [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * 1 cup (1,5 kg) [[Cookbook:Rice|Hot rice]] * 2 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1,5 tbsp. light [[Cookbook:Soy sauce|soy sauce]] * 1 tbsp. oyster sauce * 1 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]]
==Procedure==
# Heat the oil on a non-stick pan, fry the big onion and garlic, and stir at 25 seconds. Stir until fragrant. # Add the rice, and then add all the vegetables, finally add some salt, light soy sauce, oyster sauce and pepper. Stir until mixed all. # Serve for 5 plates.
[[Category:Rice recipes]] [[Category:Fried rice recipes]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes]]

revision.comment: Koavf moved page [[Cookbook:Stir fried seafood with noodles]] to [[Cookbook:Stir Fried Seafood with Noodles]]
revision.text:
{{Recipesummary|Noodle recipes|4|20 minutes|Image=[[Image:HK style pan-fried noodles 2.JPG|300px]]|2}}
{{Recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Noodle|Noodle]] |
==Ingredients==
* 1 pack (500 g) Hong Kong style [[Cookbook:Noodle|egg noodles]], rehydrated and boiled if needed * 2 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] * 2 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], crushed * 5 fishball, cut 1 cm * 200 g [[Cookbook:Shrimp|shrimp]], remove the shell (leave the tail: optional) * 100 g [[Cookbook:Cabbage|cabbage]], cut to a size that can be conveniently eaten * 2 [[Cookbook:Scallion|scallion]], cut 1 cm * 150 g [[Cookbook:Bean Sprout|bean sprouts]], rinsed in hot water * 2 tbsp. light [[Cookbook:Soy sauce|soy sauce]] * 1 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 1 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]]
==Dressing==
* 2 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Onion|Fried onion]]
==Procedure==
# Heat the oil on a non-stick pan, fry the garlic for about 10 seconds until golden brown # Add the fishball and shrimp. Stir fry until the shrimp and fishball just begin to change color. # Add the cabbage and scallion and stir fry at least until all ingredients are hot. # Add the noodles and stir fry until all ingredients are hot. # Add the bean sprouts, light soy sauce, salt, sugar and pepper. Mix well and stir fry (perhaps on reduced heat) until all ingredients are hot, taking care to not cook so long as to overly wilt the bean sprouts. # Serve immediately with fried onion.
[[Category:Seafood recipes]] [[Category:Shrimp recipes]] [[Category:Noodle recipes]] [[Category:Sprout recipes]] [[Category:Stir fry recipes]] [[Category:Asian recipes]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units]]

revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Rice recipes|5|40 minutes|2||80 kcal.}}
{{recipe}} | [[Category:Rice recipes|Rice recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Rice|Rice]] | [[Cookbook:Curry|Curry]] | [[Category:Curry recipes|Curry recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian cuisine]]
==Ingredients==
* 3 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Oil|cooking oil]] * 2 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Sesame Oil|sesame oil]] * 2 cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], crushed and minced * 2 [[Cookbook:Scallion|scallion]], cut 2 cm * 200 g [[Cookbook:Beef|sukiyaki beef]] * 100 g [[Cookbook:Bean Sprout|bean sprouts]], soak in hot water * 200 g [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]], diced * 1 cup (600 g) [[Cookbook:Basmati rice|Basmati rice, cooked]] * 10 g [[Cookbook:Chilli Powder|Chilli powder]] * 20 g [[Cookbook:Curry Powder|curry powder]] * 2 tbsp. light [[Cookbook:Soy Sauce|soy sauce]] * 1 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]]
==Procedure==
# Heat the oil and sesame oil on non-stick pan, fry the garlic and scallion until fragrant. Add sukiyaki beef and chicken, stir at 1 minutes until golden brown. # Add bean sprouts, basmati rice, chilli powder and curry powder. And then add soy sauce, salt and pepper. Stir until mixed all. # Serve for 5.
[[Category:Indian recipes]] [[Category:Curry powder recipes]] [[Category:Fried rice recipes]]

revision.comment: robot Adding: [[es:lgebra Lineal/Espacios Vectoriales]], [[fr:Algbre linaire/Espace Vectoriel]], [[pt:lgebra linear/Espaos vetoriais]]
revision.text:
<noinclude>{{navigation|Book=Linear Algebra |current=Vector Spaces |previous=Topic: Speed of Gauss' Method |next=Definition of Vector Space}}</noinclude> The first chapter began by introducing Gauss' method and finished with a fair understanding, keyed on the Linear Combination Lemma, of how it finds the solution set of a linear system. Gauss' method systematically takes linear combinations of the rows. With that insight, we now move to a general study of linear combinations.
We need a setting for this study. At times in the first chapter, we've combined vectors from <math>\mathbb{R}^2</math>, at other times vectors from <math>\mathbb{R}^3</math>, and at other times vectors from even higher-dimensional spaces. Thus, our first impulse might be to work in <math>\mathbb{R}^n</math>, leaving <math>n</math> unspecified. This would have the advantage that any of the results would hold for <math>\mathbb{R}^2</math> and for <math>\mathbb{R}^3</math> and for many other spaces, simultaneously.
But, if having the results apply to many spaces at once is advantageous then sticking only to <math>\mathbb{R}^n</math>'s is overly restrictive. We'd like the results to also apply to combinations of row vectors, as in the final section of the first chapter. We've even seen some spaces that are not just a collection of all of the same-sized column vectors or row vectors. For instance, we've seen a solution set of a homogeneous system that is a plane, inside of <math>\mathbb{R}^3</math>. This solution set is a closed system in the sense that a linear combination of these solutions is also a solution. But it is not just a collection of all of the three-tall column vectors; only some of them are in this solution set.
We want the results about linear combinations to apply anywhere that linear combinations are sensible. We shall call any such set a '''vector space'''. Our results, instead of being phrased as "Whenever we have a collection in which we can sensibly take linear combinations ...", will be stated as "In any vector space ...".
Such a statement describes at once what happens in many spaces. The step up in abstraction from studying a single space at a time to studying a class of spaces can be hard to make. To understand its advantages, consider this analogy. Imagine that the government made laws one person at a time: "Leslie Jones can't jay walk." That would be a bad idea; statements have the virtue of economy when they apply to many cases at once. Or, suppose that they ruled, "Kim Ke must stop when passing the scene of an accident." Contrast that with, "Any doctor must stop when passing the scene of an accident." More general statements, in some ways, are clearer.
<noinclude>{{navigation|Book=Linear Algebra |current=Vector Spaces |previous=Topic: Speed of Gauss' Method |next=Definition of Vector Space}}
{{BookCat}} </noinclude>
[[es:lgebra Lineal/Espacios Vectoriales]] [[fr:Algbre linaire/Espace Vectoriel]] [[pt:lgebra linear/Espaos vetoriais]]

page.title: Linear Algebra/Definition and Examples of Vector Spaces

revision.comment: /* Exercises */ removed a solution listed as excersise and fixed numbering
revision.text:
<noinclude>{{navigation|Book=Linear Algebra
|current=Definition and Examples of Vector Spaces
|previous=Definition of Vector Space
|next=Subspaces and Spanning sets}}</noinclude>
{{TextBox|1=
;Definition 1.1{{anchor|def:VecSpace}}:<!--\label{def:VecSpace}-->
A '''vector space'''
(over <math> \mathbb{R} </math>) consists of a set <math> V </math> along with
two operations "+" and "<math> \cdot </math>" subject to these conditions.

<ol type=1 start=1>
<li> For any <math> \vec{v},\vec{w}\in V </math>, their '''vector sum''' <math> \vec{v}+\vec{w} </math> is an element of <math> V </math>.
<li> If <math>\vec{v},\vec{w}\in V </math>, then <math> \vec{v}+\vec{w}=\vec{w}+\vec{v} </math>.
<li> For any <math>\vec{u},\vec{v},\vec{w}\in V </math>, <math> (\vec{v}+\vec{w})+\vec{u}=\vec{v}+(\vec{w}+\vec{u}) </math>.
<li> There is a '''zero vector''' <math> \vec{0}\in V </math> such that <math> \vec{v}+\vec{0}=\vec{v}\, </math> for all <math> \vec{v}\in V</math>.
<li> Each <math> \vec{v}\in V </math> has an '''additive inverse''' <math> \vec{w}\in V </math> such that <math> \vec{w}+\vec{v}=\vec{0} </math>.
<li> If <math> r</math> is a '''scalar''', that is, a member of <math> \mathbb{R} </math> and <math> \vec{v}\in V </math> then the '''scalar multiple''' <math> r\cdot\vec{v} </math> is in <math> V </math>.
<li> If <math> r,s\in\mathbb{R} </math> and <math> \vec{v}\in V </math> then <math> (r+s)\cdot\vec{v}=r\cdot\vec{v}+s\cdot\vec{v} </math>.
<li> If <math> r\in\mathbb{R} </math> and <math> \vec{v},\vec{w}\in V </math>, then <math> r\cdot(\vec{v}+\vec{w})=r\cdot\vec{v}+r\cdot\vec{w} </math>.
<li> If <math> r,s\in\mathbb{R} </math> and <math> \vec{v}\in V</math>, then <math> (rs)\cdot\vec{v} =r\cdot(s\cdot\vec{v}) </math>
<li> For any <math> \vec{v}\in V </math>, <math> 1\cdot\vec{v}=\vec{v} </math>.
}}

{{TextBox|1=
;Remark 1.2:
Because it involves two kinds of addition and two kinds of multiplication, that definition may seem confused. For instance, in condition 7 "<math> (r+s)\cdot\vec{v}=r\cdot\vec{v}+s\cdot\vec{v}\, </math>", the first "+" is the real number addition operator while the "+" to the right of the equals sign represents vector addition in the structure <math> V </math>. These expressions aren't ambiguous because, e.g., <math> r </math> and <math> s </math> are real numbers so "<math> r+s </math>" can only mean real number addition.
}}

{{anchor|closure}}The best way to go through the examples below is to check all ten conditions in the definition. That check is written out at length in the first example. Use it as a model for the others. Especially important are the first condition "<math> \vec{v}+\vec{w} </math> is in <math> V </math>" and the sixth condition "<math> r\cdot\vec{v} </math> is in <math> V </math>". These are the '''closure''' conditions. They specify that the addition and scalar multiplication operations are always sensible— they are defined for every pair of vectors, and every scalar and vector, and the result of the operation is a member of the set (see [[#ex:PlaneThruOriginSubsp|Example 1.4]]<!--\ref{ex:PlaneThruOriginSubsp}-->).

{{TextBox|1=
;Example 1.3{{anchor|ex:RealVecSpaces}}: <!--\label{ex:RealVecSpaces}-->
The set <math> \mathbb{R}^2 </math> is a vector space if the operations "<math> + </math>" and "<math> \cdot </math>" have their usual meaning.

:<math>
\begin{pmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{pmatrix}
+
\begin{pmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \end{pmatrix}
=
\begin{pmatrix} x_1+y_1 \\ x_2+y_2 \end{pmatrix}
\qquad
r\cdot
\begin{pmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{pmatrix}
=
\begin{pmatrix} rx_1 \\ rx_2 \end{pmatrix}
</math>

We shall check all of the conditions.

There are five conditions in item 1. For 1, closure of addition, note that for any <math> v_1,v_2,w_1,w_2\in\mathbb{R} </math> the result of the sum


:<math>
\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}
+\begin{pmatrix} w_1 \\ w_2 \end{pmatrix}
=\begin{pmatrix} v_1+w_1 \\ v_2+w_2 \end{pmatrix}
</math>


is a column array with two real entries, and so is in <math> \mathbb{R}^2 </math>. For 2, that addition of vectors commutes, take all entries to be real numbers and compute

:<math>
\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}
+\begin{pmatrix} w_1 \\ w_2 \end{pmatrix}
=\begin{pmatrix} v_1+w_1 \\ v_2+w_2 \end{pmatrix}
=\begin{pmatrix} w_1+v_1 \\ w_2+v_2 \end{pmatrix}
=\begin{pmatrix} w_1 \\ w_2 \end{pmatrix}
+\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}
</math>

(the second equality follows from the fact that the components of the vectors are real numbers, and the addition of real numbers is commutative). Condition 3, associativity of vector addition, is similar.

:<math>\begin{array}{rl}
(\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}
+\begin{pmatrix} w_1 \\ w_2 \end{pmatrix})
+\begin{pmatrix} u_1 \\ u_2 \end{pmatrix}
&=\begin{pmatrix} (v_1+w_1)+u_1 \\ (v_2+w_2)+u_2 \end{pmatrix} \\
&=\begin{pmatrix} v_1+(w_1+u_1) \\ v_2+(w_2+u_2) \end{pmatrix} \\
&=\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}
+(\begin{pmatrix} w_1 \\ w_2 \end{pmatrix}
+\begin{pmatrix} u_1 \\ u_2 \end{pmatrix})
\end{array}</math>

For the fourth condition we must produce a zero element— the vector of zeroes is it.

:<math>
\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}
+\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}
=\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}
</math>

For 5, to produce an additive inverse, note that for any <math>v_1,v_2\in\mathbb{R}</math> we have

:<math>
\begin{pmatrix} -v_1 \\ -v_2 \end{pmatrix}
+\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}
=\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}
</math>

so the first vector is the desired additive inverse of the second.

The checks for the five conditions having to do with scalar multiplication are just as routine. For 6, closure under scalar multiplication, where <math>r, v_1, v_2 \in \mathbb{R}</math>,


:<math>
r\cdot\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}
=\begin{pmatrix} rv_1 \\ rv_2 \end{pmatrix}
</math>

is a column array with two real entries, and so is in <math> \mathbb{R}^2 </math>. Next, this checks 7.

:<math>
(r+s)\cdot\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}
=\begin{pmatrix} (r+s)v_1 \\ (r+s)v_2 \end{pmatrix}
=\begin{pmatrix} rv_1+sv_1 \\ rv_2+sv_2 \end{pmatrix}
=r\cdot\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}+s\cdot\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}
</math>

For 8, that scalar multiplication distributes from the left over vector addition, we have this.

:<math>
r\cdot(\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}+\begin{pmatrix} w_1 \\ w_2 \end{pmatrix})
=\begin{pmatrix} r(v_1+w_1) \\ r(v_2+w_2) \end{pmatrix}
=\begin{pmatrix} rv_1+rw_1 \\ rv_2+rw_2 \end{pmatrix}
=r\cdot\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}+r\cdot\begin{pmatrix} w_1 \\ w_2 \end{pmatrix}
</math>

The ninth

:<math>
(rs)\cdot\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}
=\begin{pmatrix} (rs)v_1 \\ (rs)v_2 \end{pmatrix}
=\begin{pmatrix} r(sv_1) \\ r(sv_2) \end{pmatrix}
=r\cdot(s\cdot\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix})
</math>

and tenth conditions are also straightforward.

:<math>
1\cdot\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}
=\begin{pmatrix} 1v_1 \\ 1v_2 \end{pmatrix}
=\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}
</math>
}}

In a similar way, each <math> \mathbb{R}^n </math> is a vector space with the usual operations of vector addition and scalar multiplication. (In <math> \mathbb{R}^1 </math>, we usually do not write the members as column vectors, i.e., we usually do not write "<math> (\pi) </math>". Instead we just write "<math> \pi </math>".)

{{TextBox|1=
;Example 1.4{{anchor|ex:PlaneThruOriginSubsp}}: <!--\label{ex:PlaneThruOriginSubsp}--> This subset of <math> \mathbb{R}^3 </math> that is a plane through the origin

:<math>
P=\{ \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} \,\big|\, x+y+z=0\}
</math>

is a vector space if "+" and "<math>\cdot</math>" are interpreted in this way.

:<math>
\begin{pmatrix} x_1 \\ y_1 \\ z_1 \end{pmatrix}
+
\begin{pmatrix} x_2 \\ y_2 \\ z_2 \end{pmatrix}
=
\begin{pmatrix} x_1+x_2 \\ y_1+y_2 \\ z_1+z_2 \end{pmatrix}
\qquad
r\cdot
\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}
=
\begin{pmatrix} rx \\ ry \\ rz \end{pmatrix}
</math>

{{anchor|inherited operations}}The addition and scalar multiplication operations here are just the ones of <math> \mathbb{R}^3 </math>, reused on its subset <math>P</math>. We say that <math> P </math> '''inherits''' these operations from <math> \mathbb{R}^3 </math>. This example of an addition in <math>P</math>

:<math>
\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix}+\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ -1 \end{pmatrix}
</math>

illustrates that <math>P</math> is closed under addition. We've added two vectors from <math>P</math>— that is, with the property that the sum of their three entries is zero— and the result is a vector also in <math>P</math>. Of course, this example of closure is not a proof of closure. To prove that <math>P</math> is closed under addition, take two elements of <math>P</math>

:<math>
\begin{pmatrix} x_1 \\ y_1 \\ z_1 \end{pmatrix} \quad \begin{pmatrix} x_2 \\ y_2 \\ z_2 \end{pmatrix}
</math>

(membership in <math>P</math> means that <math>x_1+y_1+z_1=0</math> and <math>x_2+y_2+z_2=0</math>), and observe that their sum

:<math>
\begin{pmatrix} x_1+x_2 \\ y_1+y_2 \\ z_1+z_2 \end{pmatrix}
</math>

is also in <math>P</math> since its entries add <math>(x_1+x_2)+(y_1+y_2)+(z_1+z_2)=(x_1+y_1+z_1)+(x_2+y_2+z_2)</math> to <math>0</math>. To show that <math> P </math> is closed under scalar multiplication, start with a vector from <math>P</math>

:<math>
\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}
</math>

(so that <math> x+y+z=0 </math>) and then for <math> r\in\mathbb{R} </math> observe that the scalar multiple

:<math>
r\cdot\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}
=
\begin{pmatrix} rx \\ ry \\ rz \end{pmatrix}
</math>

satisfies that <math> rx+ry+rz=r(x+y+z)=0 </math>. Thus the two closure conditions are satisfied. Verification of the other conditions in the definition of a vector space are just as straightforward.
}}

{{TextBox|1=
;Example 1.5{{anchor|ex:ColsIntEntNotVS}}: <!--\label{ex:ColsIntEntNotVS}-->
[[#ex:RealVecSpaces|Example 1.3]]<!--\ref{ex:RealVecSpaces}--> shows that the set of all two-tall vectors with real entries is a vector space. [[#ex:PlaneThruOriginSubsp|Example 1.4]]<!--\ref{ex:PlaneThruOriginSubsp}--> gives a subset of an <math>\mathbb{R}^n</math> that is also a vector space. In contrast with those two, consider the set of two-tall columns with entries that are integers (under the obvious operations). This is a subset of a vector space, but it is not itself a vector space. The reason is that this set is not closed under scalar multiplication, that is, it does not satisfy condition 6. Here is a column with integer entries, and a scalar, such that the outcome of the operation

:<math>
0.5
\cdot
\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}
=
\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1.5 \end{pmatrix}
</math>

is not a member of the set, since its entries are not all integers.
}}

{{TextBox|1=
;Example 1.6{{anchor|ex:TrivSbspReFour}}: <!--\label{ex:TrivSbspReFour}-->
The singleton set

:<math>
\{ \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \}
</math>

is a vector space under the operations

:<math>
\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}
+
\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}
=
\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}
\qquad
r\cdot
\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}
=
\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}
</math>

that it inherits from <math> \mathbb{R}^4 </math>.
}}

A vector space must have at least one element, its zero vector. Thus a one-element vector space is the smallest one possible.

{{TextBox|1=
;Definition 1.7:
{{anchor|trival space}}A one-element vector space is a '''trivial''' space.
}}

{{TextBox|1=
;Warning!:
The examples so far involve sets of column vectors with the usual operations. But vector spaces need not be collections of column vectors, or even of row vectors. Below are some other types of vector spaces. The term "vector space" does not mean "collection of columns of reals". It means something more like "collection in which any linear combination is sensible".
}}

==Examples==
{{TextBox|1=
;Example 1.8{{anchor|ex:PolySpaceThree}}: <!--\label{ex:PolySpaceThree}-->
Consider <math> \mathcal{P}_3=\{a_0+a_1x+a_2x^2+a_3x^3\,\big|\, a_0,\ldots,a_3\in\mathbb{R}\} </math>, the set of polynomials of degree three or less (in this book, we'll take constant polynomials, including the zero polynomial, to be of degree zero). It is a vector space under the operations

:<math>
(a_0+a_1x+a_2x^2+a_3x^3)+(b_0+b_1x+b_2x^2+b_3x^3)
</math>
::<math>
=(a_0+b_0)+(a_1+b_1)x+(a_2+b_2)x^2+(a_3+b_3)x^3
</math>

and

:<math>
r\cdot(a_0+a_1x+a_2x^2+a_3x^3)=(ra_0)+(ra_1)x+(ra_2)x^2+(ra_3)x^3
</math>

(the verification is easy). This vector space is worthy of attention because these are the polynomial operations familiar from high school algebra. For instance, <math>3\cdot(1-2x+3x^2-4x^3)-2\cdot(2-3x+x^2-(1/2)x^3)=-1+7x^2-11x^3</math>.

Although this space is not a subset of any <math> \mathbb{R}^n </math>, there is a sense in which we can think of <math>\mathcal{P}_3</math> as "the same" as <math> \mathbb{R}^4 </math>. If we identify these two spaces's elements in this way


:<math>
a_0+a_1x+a_2x^2+a_3x^3
\quad\text{corresponds to}\quad
\begin{pmatrix} a_0 \\ a_1 \\ a_2 \\ a_3 \end{pmatrix}
</math>

then the operations also correspond. Here is an example of corresponding additions.

:<math>
\begin{array}{lr}
&1-2x+0x^2+1x^3 \\
+ &2+3x+7x^2-4x^3 \\ \hline
&3+1x+7x^2-3x^3
\end{array}
\quad\text{corresponds to}\quad
\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}
+
\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \\ 7 \\ -4 \end{pmatrix}
=
\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 1 \\ 7 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}
</math>

Things we are thinking of as "the same" add to "the same" sum. Chapter Three makes precise this idea of vector space correspondence. For now we shall just leave it as an intuition.
}}

{{TextBox|1=
;Example 1.9{{anchor|ex:MatSpaceTwoByTwo}}: <!--\label{ex:MatSpaceTwoByTwo}-->
The set <math> \mathcal{M}_{2 \! \times \! 2} </math> of <math> 2 \! \times \! 2 </math> matrices with real number entries is a vector space under the natural entry-by-entry operations.


:<math>
\begin{pmatrix}
a  &b \\
c  &d
\end{pmatrix}
+
\begin{pmatrix}
w  &x \\
y  &z
\end{pmatrix}
=
\begin{pmatrix}
a+w  &b+x \\
c+y  &d+z
\end{pmatrix}
\qquad
r\cdot
\begin{pmatrix}
a  &b \\
c  &d
\end{pmatrix}
=
\begin{pmatrix}
ra  &rb \\
rc  &rd
\end{pmatrix}
</math>


As in the prior example, we can think of this space as "the same" as <math> \mathbb{R}^4 </math>.
}}

{{TextBox|1=
;Example 1.10{{anchor|ex:FcnsNToRIsVecSp}}: <!--\label{ex:FcnsNToRIsVecSp}-->
The set <math> \{f\,\big|\, f:\mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{R}\} </math> of all real-valued functions of one natural number variable is a vector space under the operations

:<math>
(f_1+f_2)\,(n)=f_1(n)+f_2(n)
\qquad
(r\cdot f)\,(n)=r\,f(n)
</math>

so that if, for example, <math> f_1(n)=n^2+2\sin(n) </math> and <math> f_2(n)=-\sin(n)+0.5 </math> then <math> (f_1+2f_2)\,(n)=n^2+1 </math>.

We can view this space as a generalization of [[#ex:RealVecSpaces|Example 1.3]]<!--\ref{ex:RealVecSpaces}-->— instead of <math>2</math>-tall vectors, these functions are like infinitely-tall vectors.

:<math>
\begin{array}{c|c}
   n   & f(n)=n^2+1 \\ \hline
   0   &  1     \\
   1   &  2     \\
   2   &  5     \\
   3   &  10    \\
\vdots & \vdots \\
\end{array} 
\quad\text{corresponds to}\quad
\begin{pmatrix}
1           \\
2           \\
5           \\
10          \\
\vdots       \end{pmatrix}
</math>

Addition and scalar multiplication are component-wise, as in [[#ex:RealVecSpaces|Example 1.3]]<!--\ref{ex:RealVecSpaces}-->. (We can formalize "infinitely-tall" by saying that it means an infinite sequence, or that it means a function from <math>\mathbb{N}</math> to <math>\mathbb{R}</math>.)
}}

{{TextBox|1=
;Example 1.11:
The set of polynomials with real coefficients

:<math>
\{ a_0+a_1x+\cdots+a_nx^n\,\big|\, n\in\mathbb{N} \text{ and } a_0,\ldots,a_n\in\mathbb{R}\}
</math>

makes a vector space when given the natural "<math>+</math>"
:<math>
(a_0+a_1x+\cdots+a_nx^n)+(b_0+b_1x+\cdots+b_nx^n)
</math>
::<math>
=(a_0+b_0)+(a_1+b_1)x+\cdots +(a_n+b_n)x^n
</math>

and "<math>\cdot</math>".

:<math>
r\cdot (a_0+a_1x+\ldots a_nx^n)=(ra_0)+(ra_1)x+\ldots (ra_n)x^n
</math>

This space differs from the space <math>\mathcal{P}_3</math> of [[#ex:PolySpaceThree|Example 1.8]]<!--\ref{ex:PolySpaceThree}-->. This space contains not just degree three polynomials, but degree thirty polynomials and degree three hundred polynomials, too. Each individual polynomial of course is of a finite degree, but the set has no single bound on the degree of all of its members.

This example, like the prior one, can be thought of in terms of infinite-tuples. For instance, we can think of <math> 1+3x+5x^2 </math> as corresponding to <math> (1,3,5,0,0,\ldots) </math>. However, don't confuse this space with the one from [[#ex:FcnsNToRIsVecSp|Example 1.10]]<!--\ref{ex:FcnsNToRIsVecSp}-->. Each member of this set has a bounded degree, so under our correspondence there are no elements from this space matching <math> (1,2,5,10,\,\ldots\,) </math>. The vectors in this space correspond to infinite-tuples that end in zeroes.
}}

{{TextBox|1=
;Example 1.12{{anchor|ex:RealValuedFcns}}: <!--\label{ex:RealValuedFcns}-->
The set <math> \{f\,\big|\, f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}\} </math> of all real-valued functions of one real variable is a vector space under these.

:<math>
(f_1+f_2)\,(x)=f_1(x)+f_2(x)
\qquad
(r\cdot f)\,(x)=r\,f(x)
</math>

The difference between this and [[#ex:FcnsNToRIsVecSp|Example 1.10]]<!--\ref{ex:FcnsNToRIsVecSp}--> is the domain of the functions.
}}

{{TextBox|1=
;Example 1.13{{anchor|ex:ACos+BSin}}:<!--\label{ex:ACos+BSin}-->
The set <math> F=\{ a\cos\theta+b\sin\theta \,\big|\, a,b\in\mathbb{R}\} </math> of real-valued functions of the real variable <math> \theta </math> is a vector space under the operations

:<math>
(a_1\cos\theta+b_1\sin\theta)+(a_2\cos\theta+b_2\sin\theta) =(a_1+a_2)\cos\theta+(b_1+b_2)\sin\theta
</math>

and

:<math>
r\cdot (a\cos\theta+b\sin\theta)=(ra)\cos\theta+(rb)\sin\theta
</math>

inherited from the space in the prior example. (We can think of <math> F </math> as "the same" as <math> \mathbb{R}^2 </math> in that <math>a\cos\theta+b\sin\theta</math> corresponds to the vector with components <math>a</math> and <math>b</math>.)
}}

{{TextBox|1=
;Example 1.14:
The set

:<math>
\{f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} \,\big|\, \dfrac{d^2f}{dx^2}+f=0\}
</math>

is a vector space under the, by now natural, interpretation.

:<math>
(f+g)\,(x)=f(x)+g(x)
\qquad
(r\cdot f)\,(x)=r\,f(x)
</math>

In particular, notice that closure is a consequence:

:<math>
\frac{d^2(f+g)}{dx^2}+(f+g)
=(\frac{d^2f}{dx^2}+f)+(\frac{d^2g}{dx^2}+g)
</math>

and

:<math>
\frac{d^2(rf)}{dx^2}+(rf)
=r(\frac{d^2 f}{dx^2}+f)
</math>


of basic Calculus. This turns out to equal the space from the prior example— functions satisfying this differential equation have the form <math>a\cos\theta+b\sin\theta</math>— but this description suggests an extension to solutions sets of other differential equations.
}}

{{TextBox|1=
;Example 1.15:
The set of solutions of a homogeneous linear system in <math> n </math> variables is a vector space under the operations inherited from <math> \mathbb{R}^n </math>. For closure under addition, if

:<math>
\vec{v}=\begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ \vdots \\ v_n \end{pmatrix}
\qquad
\vec{w}=\begin{pmatrix} w_1 \\ \vdots \\ w_n \end{pmatrix}
</math>

both satisfy the condition that their entries add to <math> 0 </math> then <math> \vec{v}+\vec{w} </math> also satisfies that condition: <math> c_1(v_1+w_1)+\cdots+c_n(v_n+w_n) =(c_1v_1+\cdots+c_nv_n)+(c_1w_1+\cdots+c_nw_n) =0 </math>. The checks of the other conditions are just as routine.
}}

As we've done in those equations, we often omit the multiplication symbol "<math> \cdot </math>". We can distinguish the multiplication in "<math> c_1v_1 </math>" from that in "<math> r\vec{v}\, </math>" since if both multiplicands are real numbers then real-real multiplication must be meant, while if one is a vector then scalar-vector multiplication must be meant.

The prior example has brought us full circle since it is one of our motivating examples.

{{TextBox|1=
;Remark 1.16:
Now, with some feel for the kinds of structures that satisfy the definition of a vector space, we can reflect on that definition. For example, why specify in the definition the condition that <math> 1\cdot\vec{v}=\vec{v} </math> but not a condition that <math> 0\cdot\vec{v}=\vec{0} </math>?

One answer is that this is just a definition— it gives the rules of the game from here on, and if you don't like it, put the book down and walk away.

Another answer is perhaps more satisfying. People in this area have worked hard to develop the right balance of power and generality. This definition has been shaped so that it contains the conditions needed to prove all of the interesting and important properties of spaces of linear combinations. As we proceed, we shall derive all of the properties natural to collections of linear combinations from the conditions given in the definition.

The next result is an example. We do not need to include these properties in the definition of vector space because they follow from the properties already listed there.
}}

{{TextBox|1=
;Lemma 1.17:
In any vector space <math> V </math>, for any <math> \vec{v}\in V </math> and <math> r\in\mathbb{R} </math>, we have
# <math> 0\cdot\vec{v}=\vec{0} </math>, and
# <math> (-1\cdot\vec{v})+\vec{v}=\vec{0} </math>, and
# <math> r\cdot\vec{0}=\vec{0} </math>.
}}

{{TextBox|1=
;Proof:
For 1, note that <math> \vec{v}=(1+0)\cdot\vec{v}=\vec{v}+(0\cdot\vec{v}) </math>. Add to both sides the additive inverse of <math> \vec{v} </math>, the vector <math> \vec{w} </math> such that <math> \vec{w}+\vec{v}=\vec{0} </math>.

:<math>\begin{array}{rl}
\vec{w}+\vec{v}
&=\vec{w}+\vec{v}+0\cdot\vec{v} \\
\vec{0}
&=\vec{0}+0\cdot\vec{v} \\
\vec{0}
&=0\cdot\vec{v}
\end{array}</math>


The second item is easy: <math> (-1\cdot\vec{v})+\vec{v}=(-1+1)\cdot\vec{v}=0\cdot\vec{v}=\vec{0} </math> shows that we can write "<math> -\vec{v}\, </math>" for the additive inverse of <math> \vec{v} </math> without worrying about possible confusion with <math> (-1)\cdot\vec{v} </math>.

For 3, this <math> r\cdot\vec{0}=r\cdot(0\cdot\vec{0})=(r\cdot 0)\cdot\vec{0}=\vec{0} </math> will do.
}}

==Summary==
We finish with a recap.

Our study in Chapter One of Gaussian reduction led us to consider collections of linear combinations. So in this chapter we have defined a vector space to be a structure in which we can form such combinations, expressions of the form <math> c_1\cdot\vec{v}_1+\dots+c_n\cdot\vec{v}_n </math> (subject to simple conditions on the addition and scalar multiplication operations). In a phrase: vector spaces are the right context in which to study linearity.

Finally, a comment. From the fact that it forms a whole chapter, and especially because that chapter is the first one, a reader could come to think that the study of linear systems is our purpose. The truth is, we will not so much use vector spaces in the study of linear systems as we will instead have linear systems start us on the study of vector spaces. The wide variety of examples from this subsection shows that the study of vector spaces is interesting and important in its own right, aside from how it helps us understand linear systems. Linear systems won't go away. But from now on our primary objects of study will be vector spaces.

</ol>

:<math>
\begin{pmatrix}
1  &-1  \\
0  &3
\end{pmatrix}.
</math>

<li> In <math> \{ae^x+be^{-x}\,\big|\, a,b\in\mathbb{R}\} </math>, the space of functions of the real variable <math> x </math> under the natural operations, the vector <math> 3e^x-2e^{-x} </math>.
</ol>

under the operations inherited from <math>\mathbb{R}^4</math>.

A '''vector space over the complex numbers''' <math>\mathbb{C}</math> has the same definition as a vector space over the reals except that scalars are drawn from <math> \mathbb{C} </math> instead of from <math> \mathbb{R} </math>. Show that each of these is a vector space over the complex numbers. (Recall how complex numbers add and multiply: <math> (a_0+a_1i)+(b_0+b_1i)=(a_0+b_0)+(a_1+b_1)i </math> and <math> (a_0+a_1i)(b_0+b_1i)=(a_0b_0-a_1b_1)+(a_0b_1+a_1b_0)i </math>.)
<ol type=1 start=1>
<li> The set of degree two polynomials with complex coefficients
<li> This set

:<math>
\{\begin{pmatrix}
0  &a  \\
b  &0
\end{pmatrix}\,\big|\, a,b\in\mathbb{C}\text{ and }
a+b=0+0i \}
</math>

</ol>
}}
{{TextBox|1=
;Problem 25:
Name a property shared by all of the <math> \mathbb{R}^n </math>'s but not listed as a requirement for a vector space.
}}
{{Linear Algebra/Book 2/Recommended}}
{{TextBox|1=
;Problem 26:
<ol type=1 start=1>
<li> Prove that a sum of four vectors <math> \vec{v}_1,\ldots,\vec{v}_4\in V </math> can be associated in any way without changing the result.

:<math>\begin{array}{rl}
((\vec{v}_1+\vec{v}_2)+\vec{v}_3)+\vec{v}_4
&=(\vec{v}_1+(\vec{v}_2+\vec{v}_3))+\vec{v}_4 \\
&=(\vec{v}_1+\vec{v}_2)+(\vec{v}_3+\vec{v}_4) \\
&=\vec{v}_1+((\vec{v}_2+\vec{v}_3)+\vec{v}_4) \\
&=\vec{v}_1+(\vec{v}_2+(\vec{v}_3+\vec{v}_4))
\end{array}</math>

This allows us to simply write "<math> \vec{v}_1+\vec{v}_2+\vec{v}_3+\vec{v}_4 </math>" without ambiguity.
<li> Prove that any two ways of associating a sum of any number of vectors give the same sum. (''Hint.'' Use induction on the number of vectors.)
</ol>
}}
{{TextBox|1=
;Problem 27:
For any vector space, a subset that is itself a vector space under the inherited operations (e.g., a plane through the origin inside of <math> \mathbb{R}^3 </math>) is a '''subspace'''.
<ol type=1 start=1>
<li> Show that <math> \{a_0+a_1x+a_2x^2\,\big|\, a_0+a_1+a_2=0\} </math> is a subspace of the vector space of degree two polynomials.
<li> Show that this is a subspace of the <math> 2 \! \times \! 2 </math> matrices.

:<math>
\{\begin{pmatrix}
a  &b  \\
c  &0
\end{pmatrix} \,\big|\, a+b=0\}
</math>

<li> Show that a nonempty subset <math> S </math> of a real vector space is a subspace if and only if it is closed under linear combinations of pairs of vectors: whenever <math> c_1,c_2\in\mathbb{R} </math> and <math> \vec{s}_1,\vec{s}_2\in S </math> then the combination <math> c_1\vec{v}_1+c_2\vec{v}_2 </math> is in <math> S </math>.
</ol>
}}
<noinclude>
[[/Solutions/]]

{{navigation|Book=Linear Algebra
|current=Definition and Examples of Vector Spaces
|previous=Definition of Vector Space
|next=Subspaces and Spanning sets}}

{{BookCat}}
</noinclude>
